title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the average fixed cost as $0.75 and/or does not show the work.

AFC= TFC Q = $3 4 =$0.75 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4515@

The response calculates the average fixed cost as $0.75 and shows the work.

AFC= TFC Q = $3 4 =$0.75 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4515@

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the profit-maximizing quantity as 3 units and/or does not explain that the 3rd unit is the last unit where the marginal revenue ($12) is greater than the marginal cost ($10); the firm will not produce the 4th unit because the marginal cost of producing it ($14) is greater than the marginal revenue earned ($12).

The response identifies the profit-maximizing quantity as 3 units and explains that the 3rd unit is the last unit where the marginal revenue ($12) is greater than the marginal cost ($10); the firm will not produce the 4th unit because the marginal cost of producing it ($14) is greater than the marginal revenue earned ($12).

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the economic profit as $8 and/or does not show the work.

Economic Profit=TR−TC=3( $12 )−$28=$8 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@53F0@

The response calculates the economic profit as $8 and shows the work.

Economic Profit=TR−TC=3( $12 )−$28=$8 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@53F0@

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the number of firms in the industry will increase and/or does not explain that positive economic profit will attract new firms to enter the industry.
The response states that the number of firms in the industry will increase and explains that positive economic profit will attract new firms to enter the industry.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the market price will decrease and/or does not explain that with the entry of firms, the market supply will increase, causing the price to decrease.
The response states that the market price will decrease and explains that with the entry of firms, the market supply will increase, causing the price to decrease.

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the demand for balls of yarn will increase and/or does not explain that the negative cross-price elasticity of demand for balls of yarn with respect to the price of Good R means that the goods are complements; therefore, a decrease in the price of Good R will lead to an increase in the demand for balls of yarn.

The response states that that the demand for balls of yarn will increase and explains that the negative cross-price elasticity of demand for balls of yarn with respect to the price of Good R means that the goods are complements; therefore, a decrease in the price of Good R will lead to an increase in the demand for balls of yarn.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does none of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good R will decrease and explains that shipping costs per order are a variable cost, so an increase in shipping costs per order will shift the marginal cost curve upward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a lower quantity.

· States that total economic surplus will stay the same and explains that a price ceiling above equilibrium is not binding and will not affect the number of transactions in the market.

The response does one of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good R will decrease and explains that shipping costs per order are a variable cost, so an increase in shipping costs per order will shift the marginal cost curve upward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a lower quantity.

· States that total economic surplus will stay the same and explains that a price ceiling above equilibrium is not binding and will not affect the number of transactions in the market.

The response does both of the following:

· States that the profit-maximizing quantity of Good R will decrease and explains that shipping costs per order are a variable cost, so an increase in shipping costs per order will shift the marginal cost curve upward at each quantity so that marginal cost will intersect marginal revenue at a lower quantity.

· States that total economic surplus will stay the same and explains that a price ceiling above equilibrium is not binding and will not affect the number of transactions in the market.
